bibl.title: Despatches from United States Consuls in Gaboon, 1856-1888 T-466

text.body:
Gaboon Nov. 26th 1866
Monsieur the Commandant Superior of the French settlements, West Coast of Africa
We the undersigned merchants established at Gaboon having been made acquirable with the circular which was addressed to us by your order on the 16th of this month, and in accordance with your invitation on the occasion of our visit to you on the 24th of September last on the subject of the circular dated the 21st of the smae month Have the honor to state to you that which follows.
The merchantile community of Gaboon was painfully impressed on learning by the announcement contained in your first circular that the other country having thought proper to evade the local expenses you should deem it necessary to make it support the amount of this contain commencing by causing no to pay for licenses, which or consider to be very high if compared to those paid in France when trade is so much more important than have.
That moreever when we established ourselves at Gaboon we were far from forcing that so sudden a change would one day come upon us and in a manners so burdensome in were so mad. the firtters from supposing it suing that the country is one of the protest and must son unhealthy of the Coast of Africa.
With regard to the second circular relative to the duties to be informatives and Exportationa of merchandise we can only repeat to you that which we have said before with regard to the besiners*unclear that thee mercantile community is totally unable to be ring of
there expenses and this you will perfectly understand by the state musst which one *unclear* to forward to you.
Barwood the principal return cargo does not pay freight, this is easily seen, the present selling price in France being 75 to 85 francs at most per ton.
Ebony is but of shore* sale, after being kept a long time in warehouses and consequenity after heavy exposure .
India Rubber beemes daily searen , and even may be said to be disappearing entirdy besides this it sustains great lop of overnights, it in river the lop the most important article.
Ivory is purchased at a *unclear* rate here than in Europe, consequently the profit denied from it in my small, and consists only in the your made in lasting the goods.
Busway, this product is so scarce that it snag be considered *unclear*
To all this we have to add that living becomes harder daily, fresh provisions being wanting so to speak moreover we *unclear* to otherwise than have your attention to the enormous lesser which wwe sustain by the frquent plundering of our boats, and this in spirit of your goal wise. As to the trust given to the natives, we will not enlarge on that subject, and yet you an perfectly aware that those advances once made may be considered as therefourth last.
That circular also contained seward articles relative to the keeping of our Books, on this head we will beg you to notice that in a country where one can remain but a short time, and is often ill, it is impossible to keep accounts as reguarly as in France.
In addition, profilin by this opportunity we think that as ought to draw your attention to the fact, that the formalities to be fulfilled. because daily more complicates, thus we are obliged before commencing the unloading or leading of a vessel to obtain a permit at the cost of a franc. There appears to us the necessity for the existance of this permit in a country where until now the authorities having nothing to gain thereby has never occupied itself with this kind of operation this measure occasioning some time a delay cannot but be prejudicial to us.
Hoping Monseiurs will be pleased to tkae into consideration the different observations which we have the honor to address to you and that in your high sease of Justice you will recognise the impossibility of insising upon the executive of the said circular of Sept 21st and Nov 16th.
We have the honor to be Your most humble and Very obedient Servant.
Signed, E.Pilartres Vieteria +Cubarey from Robert Kirkwood E.Hannah William Latta John L Wookey Jon Thormahlin
